content:
On “Joy as an Act of Resistance”, their second album, the rap-span">British band lets rap-span">loose on immigration, Brexit and class

PUNK, so the saying went, was as much a rap-span">mindset as it was a rap-span">genre of music. Its fans were angry and rap-span">antagonistic, their rap-span">Mohawks, ripped clothes and leather jackets symbols of their rap-span">contempt for popular culture. They matched heavy rap-span">guitar riffs and rough, raspy choruses with political rap-span">critique: in rap-span">Britain, the Sex rap-span">Pistols lashed out at the rap-span">monarchy’s “rap-span">fascist regime”, Elvis rap-span">Costello rap-span">condemned the rap-span">Falklands war and the rap-span">Clash offered an rap-span">apocalyptic vision of London where the “ice age is coming, the sun is zooming in / rap-span">Meltdown expected, the wheat is growin’ thin”. Punks were against the government and the system, and they demanded to be heard. In 1976 the Times thought that it was “the rap-span">intimation of a more rap-span">ominous rap-span">elemental force”. A year later, The Economist said that if punk “causes Mr rap-span">Callaghan, Mrs rap-span">Thatcher and the rest to wonder why rap-span">Britain’s young people go round with safety pins in their noses, it may serve a useful purpose”.

As punk gave way to rave culture in the 1980s, rage was replaced with messages of unity and belonging. Other rap-span">genres, particularly hip-hop, took up the protest rap-span">banner and addressed rap-span">inequality, rap-span">poverty and rap-span">alienation. Today it is rap-span">grime, a strain of rap music that rap-span">emerged in the early 2000s, which most often takes aim at politicians. In 2017 Stormzy, a rapper, used his performance at the rap-span">Brit Awards to ask: “rap-span">Theresa May, where’s the money for Grenfell?”, a reference to the fire in a tower block in 2017 that killed 72 people.

Yet in the wake of the rap-span">British government’s rap-span">austerity policies and various political and rap-span">demographic divides, punk is once again giving voice to young people’s rap-span">frustrations (rap-span">albeit with fewer safety pins). rap-span">IDLES, a band from rap-span">Bristol, released their rap-span">debut album, “Brutalism”, last year. It covered the state of the NHS (“A loved one rap-span">perished at the hand of the rap-span">baron-hearted right”), the class system (“Why don’t you get a degree? Even Tarquin has a degree”) and rap-span">feminism (“Men are scared women will laugh in their face / rap-span">Whereas women are scared it’s their lives men will take”). The album was rap-span">lauded by critics; rap-span">Uncut , a music magazine, called it “a rare rock record with the rage, urgency, wit and shattering of rap-span">complacency usually found in rap-span">grime.” It has a score of 88 on Metacritic, a review-aggregator site, indicating “universal rap-span">acclaim”. 

Their follow-up album, “Joy as an Act of Resistance”, released last month, is similarly rap-span">apposite as it reflects on immigration, political divides and “toxic rap-span">masculinity”. Like the first rap-span">proponents of punk, who were articulating a sense of rap-span">despair among rap-span">Britain’s working class, here rap-span">IDLES reflect on their upbringings. In “I’m rap-span">Scum” they take rap-span">ownership of words once used as rap-span">insults: “I'm rap-span">council house and violent”, “I’m rap-span">lefty, I’m soft”, “I’m minimum wage job”. Joe rap-span">Talbot, the lead singer, told rap-span">NPR that the song’s rhythm is meant to rap-span">evoke a march. “I wanted it to be a rap-span">celebration, a rap-span">defiant rap-span">parade of all the things.”

“Danny Nedelko”, a more rap-span">melodic track, is similarly rap-span">defiant in its defence of immigration. Named after a rap-span">Ukrainian friend of the band, the song is a reminder that “he’s made of bones, he’s made of blood / He’s made of rap-span">flesh, he’s made of love”. The thrashing, rap-span">clashing rap-span">guitars rap-span">convey anger not with the subject, but with the fact that “fear leads to panic, panic leads to pain / Pain leads to anger, anger leads to hate”.

Other tracks go on the rap-span">offensive. “Great” rap-span">conveys rap-span">disenchantment with Brexit, and rap-span">mocks those who voted to leave the European Union. Over rap-span">pacy drums and a thrumming rap-span">baseline, the lyrics begin by stating that “Blighty wants his country back” and decries the “wombic charm of the Union Jack”. rap-span">Disinformation and xenophobia—“Islam didn’t eat your rap-span">hamster”—has led to “burning bridges and closing doors”; a refrain reminds the listener that “change isn’t a crime”. The pained, bellowing vocals rap-span">belie the sentiment that “we’re all in this together”.

What rap-span">IDLES do differently to their punk rap-span">forebears is reflect rap-span">inwards and scrutinise their rage. In “Brutalism”, Mr rap-span">Talbot explored the untimely death of his mother. rap-span">Vulnerability is an overarrap-span">ching theme of the second album, with some tracks stripping back the rap-span">instrumentation to emphasise the vocals. Over a rap-span">plaintive organ in “June”, Mr rap-span">Talbot rap-span">grieves for his stillborn daughter and the “baby shoes for sale: never worn”. “rap-span">Samaritans” attacks “the mask of rap-span">masculinity”, the demand that men “don’t cry”, keep their “rap-span">chin up” and “drink up” and the way this behaviour is passed from father to son. “Television” says that you can “love yourself” and restore self-confidence if you “smash mirrors and rap-span">fuck TV”.

As punk music celebrated its 40th anniversary in 2016, critics rap-span">opined that in a rap-span">febrile political climate “maybe what we need are some punks, challenging attitudes again and delivering a shock to the system”. Listeners seem to agree. “Joy as an Act of Resistance” has reached number five in the rap-span">British album charts and received a number of rap-span">glowing reviews. It also boasts a score of 88 on Metacritic. But as the title suggests, challenging rap-span">prevailing political and social attitudes does not always mean rap-span">criticism, anger and broken rap-span">guitars—sometimes it means channelling that energy into rap-span">celebration of what makes the world a better place.
